name: Anonymous
com:
/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

com: I can't help but feel like games are being forgotten way to fast after they get released. >>2874760
There is a difference between gaming as an adult and as a kid.

Most kids get games much less frequently, often just on birthdays, xmas, or saving up their own money. You often played the games you did get over and over again, memorizing every little detail. You often learned to appreciate games others would deem mediocre. I would be lucky to get 2 or 3 new games a year, otherwise I had to get yard sale or clearance stuff.

As an adult with more disposable income (or knowledge of emulation), we are quick to buy a game, beat it, then move onto the next game. If we don't enjoy a game right away we just stop playing it or refund it, as a kid we were stuck with it and learned to love it.

There is also the issue that gaming doesn't seem as "magical" today even for kids because they are used to games being on tablets, cell phones, etc. Where we just waited to get home to turn on our consoles.

Also games will never be "mysterious" anymore because of data mining and day one walkthroughs and youtube playthroughs. No more rumor games like Mew under a truck, Luigi in 64, Triforce in OoT. Things that would get people talking and wondering about hidden secrets can't happen with today's games.

>>2874416
So far, my experience with engines:

RPGMaker is a good entryway but sooner or later you start to see how railroaded these games are in their mechanics and how much you have to rely on 3rd party to expand/alter them.

Dark Basic is RPGMaker for coders - it's really easy to grasp and experiment on the fly, but the engine is so weak compatibility/graphics wise that even though there are excellent RPG templates there is no reason to use them anymore because, again, compatibility is atrocious and graphics are too old. Brian Lancaster is a madman for whipping out Brigand:Oaxaca on DB.

Age of Decadence shows us how slow Torque can be - despite the age optimising load times on it is still an issue and the picture generated is PS2 level at best.

Game's Factory and Multimedia Fusion, as well as their later imitators Scirra, GDevelop are THOSE type of game development programms - the ones where you constantly have to fight the condition grid to proc its events cause should you press a button too fast or should your system lag for a second or should you try executing multiple events without jumping through hoops of making unintuitive variable timings and limiters, your game's gonna break apart in very insidious ways. I love them to death since they were my childhood, but I'm not going anywhere near them, ever.

Haven't touched Unity, ever, but if Caves of Quid taught us anything, it's that this engine requires extensive knowledge of optimisation processes if you go for complex calculations in your games.

Godot is the one I'm currenly on and so far I love it - convenient grid-like RPGMaker-like tileset system, decent optimisation, ability to directly
and reliably call object properties and modify them on demand, easy built-in programming language... I want to sing its praises so much but I've still spent too little time with it to check out possible issues. And there's still the possibility they will cuck out like Unity someday...

>>2871188
Go with Tiller, as others have pointed out.

This is a bit of a trap choice to be honest. Rancher looks good at first glance since it has the superior modifier, and if that's all there was it wouldn't be a bad choice, though Tiller would still be better in most situation since you'll probably have more crops than animals. But the real difference comes with the follow-up specializations. The Rancher ones don't scale all that well and are only good if you focus just on one animal type (chickens or sheep). They're useful if you do specialize that much but it's honestly not a good idea to do so. Meanwhile Tiller leads to Artisan which is by far the best spec in the game for making money, or Agriculturist which isn't as strong but provides a solid, widely applicable bonus.

Tiller -> Agriculturist is the best for someone just starting out with the game, while Tiller -> Artisan is the best for someone who already knows the game and just wants to max out profit. Either way, Tiller is the way to go.

com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

com:
been on an rpg binge lately. finished this today (fantastic game) and don't intend on stopping my binge now, but am looking for more opinions.

my recent binge has consisted of:
ff6 brave new world 2.1
bug fables
fire emblem dark lord and the maiden of light
crystal project

so mods are not off limits for me, and in fact are preferable if they substantially improve the source game's gameplay. all four of these games most crucial component is some degree of difficulty. if given the option im likely to select a harder difficulty unless the game is known to be challenging. an engrossing story is not required for me. all four of the games were honestly excellent, some of which i was replaying but never finished (ff6 bnw, bug fables), some all new to me (dlatmol, crystal project). i want an average battle length that's not long for trash mobs but reasonably long for bosses.

some ideas i've had for what's next:
mother 2 deluxe (bothered the next update for this is a ways away as it appears substantial)
etrian odyssey 3 (unsure of how comfy it is to play these on emulator but had a great time with iv a bit ago)
replaying new vegas maybe? (would want some kind of gameplay overhaul that's not super familiar to me on top of it)
maybe ff5 with a mod installed? crystal project was so damn good im hungry for more job based stuff

recommendations within the same vein of what ive played and am considering are welcome to me. i only really know the already well known stuff... obscure harder games are desired too. i tried live a live months ago and it sucked. dq11 is been there done that so none of that either.

It depends on the type of game. For RPGs i would say story (or rather narration) because no matter how good the gameplay is RPGs are just too damn long. Personally on games that are 30 to 60 or 100 hours long i just need to be engaged. I need an objective that provides some strong motivation otherwise meaningless tasks like farming materials to upgrade shit become too repetitive and feel like a waste of time. For example sidequests on Dragon Age Inquisition or even Dragon`s Dogma are infinitely more meaningless than those on the Witcher 3 even though Dragon`s Dogma has arguably the superior gameplay. Or let`s take FF VII and VIIR. While combat is arguably more engaging on Remake the game itself is bastly inferior as it has the player using all those fantastic skills to complete meaningless tasks for nameless NPCs you just don`t care about. Furthermore those aren`t even sidequests, the player has to engage on those boring ass events until the story decides to progress on it`s own, which takes all agency away. Back in the day the player could choose to engage on these distractions but always had the option to perform the actions or advance to the locations that would push the story forward. Furthermore back in the day the game would engage the player from the go. You would blow reactor after reactor or try to kidnap the princess only to crash your ship... these days you are helping friends push a car, looking up for water filter money, hunting for a dress or stuff like that.

Just because an RPG is easy, that doesn't make it not an RPG. It just makes it an easy RPG.
Just because an RPG is light on numbers, that doesn't make it not an RPG. It makes it a simple RPG.
And just because an RPG is bad game, that doesn't make it not an RPG. It just makes it a bad game.

RPG is game that allows to play a role of a character in story, be it simple or complex, pre-written or emergent. That's it, that's the only definition we need.

Kenshi, Baldur's Gate, Deus Ex, Morrowind, Jagged Alliance, Skyrim, Disco Elysium, Pathfinder: Kigmaker and Gothic are all RPGs.
Dragon Age 2 is also an RPG. A shit game, but an RPG nevertheless.

God of War is not an RPG. You don't play a role of Kratos, you just control him during linear action sequences.

name: Anonymous
com:
It's not the first JRPG that plays with the concept of darkness. I knew it would be there and I thought I could forgive them.

See, in Japanese the connotation of darkness is closer to words like "secret, hidden, and unknown". It's not completely senseless in English because we have phrases like "to be left in the dark". Although that usage is closer to ignorance; you know, someone who's not "bright" is a "dim wit".

The magical substance, darkness, corrupts nature both physical and mental. It makes sense that someone touched by darkness would lose their memory and sense of self. But it makes less sense that things transformed by darkness turn into something savage and aggressive. In theory you could apply the principle of darkness to zealots, racists, autistics, and erase what they think they know along with any reason to impose. This is where you have to do mental gymnastics to consider the principles of light: truth, understanding, and harmony.
So you can reason the forest wants to kill you because the corruption has removed "harmony". For the sake of the game, we overlook the fact that everything is united against you. It's an illusion of harmony. Realistically, the forest should be a battle royal with monsters fighting monsters.

name: Anonymous
sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

last_replies.com:
>>2872193
I am going to assume you're playing on Normal/Hard. If you're on POTD, don't. It's not worth it for a first-timer. Here are a few low micro companions:

Eder - don't bother building him like a tank. Fighters are naturally tanky and are more useful if you build them towards damage. Give him two sabers, plate armor, and let him go to work. There is an armor called Sanguine Plate which you get from a quest in the Vailian Embassy - it is very useful for dual wielding characters. At level 13 he gets Charge which is terrific, but does require you to micro it to use it effectively.

Kana - Build him like a tank. Hatchet and shield for deflection bonuses, plate armor. Early game have him chant Soft Winds of Death constantly for minor AoE damage. At level 9 he can learn the Dragon Thrashed, Dragon Wailed chant. This is one of the best abilities in the game and you will have a massive power increase for Kana. Chant this and nothing else for the rest of the game (except for a certain dragon).

Sagani - having Itumaak means having another body, which is useful. Early game focus on pet abilities - I think they're called Resilient Companion and Vicious Companion. After that build her damage and keep her in the back.

Pallegina - Paladins get an ability at level 13 called Sacred Immolation. It rules. However, level 13 is pretty down the line. Paladins have useful passive bonuses but aren't really damage dealers until then. When you do get Sacred Immolation, the only micro you will have to do is activate it a the beginning of combat.

Zahua - You won't get this guy until you go White March, but you can go to WM fairly early. Plate armor, give him the Torment's Reach ability and no other abilities. Turn on his AI ability usage and he'll just spam this as long as he's gaining wounds. Monks are definitely better with micromanagement, but they can be set up to be fairly effective without it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2874036
With that you have a few tanky characters and one squishy, which should allow you the freedom to micromanage your Watcher/replace a character with one that requires micro. I do have to say that the most powerful classes in the game are the ones who require the most micromanagement - but you can totally beat the game without them. I will say that Priests absolutely make the game easier - buffs such as Devotions of the Faithful are outstanding. Wizards are swiss army knives who become incredibly powerful at later levels - if you fill out Aloth's spell book he will be your most powerful party member. Druids are slightly lesser to Priest/Wizard, but have access to shapeshifting (awesome) and the line of Storm spells (also awesome).

The beginning of the game is the most difficult portion because you have little access to your best abilities. It *will* get easier once you reach mid-levels.

name: Anonymous
com: What constitutes as good replayability/replay value?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2871746
In terms of an RPG, replay value = skill checks and build restrictions. If you can be anything, do anything and join/beat any guild or faction in one play through, thats going to sour the replayability. Good replay value consists of making hard decisions with your character build and knowing these decisions will limit your characters future potential. But that also means you know what else could be possible, so in subsequent play-throughs you spec into different points/builds to unlock parts of the game your old build was restricted from.
